author: The Sydney Morning Herald
title: Fairfax journalists dominate business at Walkleys
text:
Fairfax Media journalists have dominated the finalists list for this year's Walkley Business Journalism Award. The shortlist was unveiled on Tuesday with Adele Ferguson garnering two nominations for her investigations into wage fraud at 7-Eleven and problems in the financial advice arm of the National Australia Bank in Australia and in Britain.
The judge's citation for the expose on 7-Eleven, which was a joint investigation by Fairfax Media and the ABC's Four Corners , said: "Shining a light on the fraudulent wage practices and staff exploitation happening every day inside one of the world's biggest brands was a complicated undertaking which involved leaked documents, whistleblowers and surveillance. Tracking the illegal operations all the way to the top of the franchise revealed gaping holes in Australia's visa and corporate arrangements."
Ferguson was jointly nominated with Fairfax Media's Sarah Danckert and the ABC's Klaus Toft.
Learn more about the 7-Eleven scandal in a Fairfax Media interactive package here or watch the Four Corners episode here

Ferguson was also nominated for a detailed series of articles revealing allegations of misconduct, forgery and fraud at National Australia Bank.
Ferguson was jointly nominated with Fairfax Media's Ruth Williams. The judges found the investigation "uncovered a corporate culture that had financially damaged hundreds of customers".
"Their revelations of the bank's quiet sacking of 37 financial planners for misconduct (of whom NAB referred only five to the regulator) exposed the bank to multiple investigations. NAB changed its internal policies and established a compensation scheme for affected customers," the citation said.
The stories are linked here: Secret documents blow the lid on forgery, poor compliance and 'rogue' advisers in NAB's financial planning arm ; NAB's scandal deepens ; and
NAB has left a trail of destruction in the United Kingdom
Former NAB planner Graeme Cowper. Photo: Nick Moir
Rounding out the nominations are Fairfax Media's Beau Donelly and Nick Toscano for their stories on Belle Gibson Exposed.
The judges citation says the pair revealed the wellness blogger had "failed to hand over money promised to charities, and their report led to the collapse of her business,The Whole Pantry, which she had built on the back of claims she'd cured herself of terminal brain cancer with a healthy diet.
"Donelly and Toscano also raised questions about why Penguin and Apple had eagerly swallowed Gibson's story."
Their stories can be read here: Charity money not handed over ; Penguin pulls Belle Gibson cookbook and Refund calls over 'cancer survivor'
Fairfax Media Australian metro media editorial director Sean Aylmer said the announcement was "a fantastic result for Fairfax and particularly Adele".
"Our teams continue to create the highest quality business journalism in the country, which improves the society in which we live," he said.
The judges selected the finalists from more than 40 entries, and said this year's entries demonstrated the value of business journalism done well.
The winners of the 60th Walkley Awards will be announced at a gala dinner on Thursday, December 3, at Crown Palladium in Melbourne. The ceremony will be broadcast live on SKY APAC or streamed live on the Walkley website from 7pm.
The judges for the 2015 Walkley Business Journalism Award were: Ros Childs, presenter, ABC News 24 and ABC Melbourne; Anne Hyland, senior writer, Fairfax Media; and Judith Sloan, Melbourne University and contributing economics editor The Australian .
